questionListItems.title: When will the school Open House be?

answer.body: The school Open House is held annually on the last Saturday of November to better support Primary 6 pupils in making informed choices. It will be held on 25 November this year.

questionListItems.title: What is the MOE-OBS Challenge Programme?

answer.body: The programme consists of pre- and post-course lessons taught by our teachers and the OBS Course led by OBS Instructors. It is designed to ensure achievement of the programme‚Äôs learning outcomes and transference of learning to other areas of the students‚Äô life. Students are not graded for performance but are encouraged to work on goals they set for themselves.

questionListItems.title: What should my child bring for the OBS Programme?

answer.body: Please refer your child to the packing list. Both the school and OBS discourage students from bringing expensive items. We encourage your child to borrow items that he/she does not have from family/friends/schoolmates to minimise unnecessary expenses. Your child‚Äôs valuables, such as mobile phones and wallets, will be kept by OBS to ensure the security of personal items and minimal distraction during the Programme.

questionListItems.title: Where can I find the schedule and details of each HBL session?

answer.body: The information of each HBL session can be found on the HBL microsite shared with the students. Alternatively, you may find the schedule on our school‚Äôs website.

questionListItems.title: What can I expect from HBL?

answer.body: HBL comprises synchronous lessons through platforms such as Zoom, as well as asynchronous lessons via online portals such as Student Learning Space (SLS). There will also be readings and assignments.

questionListItems.title: What is the duration of the HBL?

answer.body: Students should start each HBL session with a check-in with their Class Mentors at 8:00am. Thereafter, they should follow the HBL schedule and complete the necessary tasks. However, students are to be mindful of the amount of screen time when using their personal learning devices.

questionListItems.title: What happens if my child needs assistance?

answer.body: Teachers are contactable through email and any other means of communication that they have established with their students.

questionListItems.title: How will HBL impact after-school activities?

answer.body: On HBL days, there will be no activities in school that students need to attend. Parents will be notified should there be exceptions.

questionListItems.title: How many Weighted Assessments are there in a year?

answer.body: For Secondary 1 to 3 students, there will be 3 Weighted Assessments a year, one in each of Terms 1, 2 and 3. Secondary 4 and 5 students will have 2 Weighted Assessments in Terms 1 and 2.

questionListItems.title: Why are Weighted Assessments structured during curriculum time?

answer.body: Just like timetabled lessons, Weighted Assessment are part of the learning process. Structuring them during curriculum time is the most natural and conducive way for students to learn, and it also reduces assessment anxiety.

questionListItems.title: What happens if my child is unable to sit for a scheduled Weighted Assessment?

answer.body: For students who are unwell, a medical certificate must be produced. For students who are away for official reasons such as competitions, they will be allowed to reschedule their assessment within 3 school days before or after the paper. For all other cases, the school will consider them on a case-by-case basis.

questionListItems.title: What kind of activities will my child be going through during the OBS Programme?

answer.body: OBS uses the outdoors as its classroom. Your child will be engaged in a variety of activities that will help him/her not just to discover, but also challenge his/her personal limits. Some of these activities include problem-solving activities, adventure activities conducted over land and in the sea. It allows students to connect with nature and develop their resilience while cultivating a positive mindset to manage difficult situations they face.

questionListItems.title: Is the OBS Programme compulsory for my child?

answer.body: The MOE-OBS Challenge Programme is part of school curriculum for Secondary 3 students but parental consent will be sought.

questionListItems.title: How can the safety of my child be ensured during the OBS Programme, especially when they have to mingle with students from other schools?

answer.body: The positive learning experiences and well-being of your child are our priority. Activities are purposefully designed to meet the programme outcomes. The students are supervised by qualified OBS Instructors who are trained in wilderness first aid, and have undergone rigorous training, technical skills assessments and certifications. Students undergo the course in groups of up to 12-14 per Instructor, and this small group size facilitates good interaction, adequate peer support and opportunities to practise leadership roles. In addition, OBS has a robust safety monitoring system and evacuation plan for emergencies.

questionListItems.title: Does my child need to be certified fit by a medical doctor to attend the OBS Programme?

answer.body: Yes, all students attending the programme will be examined by a medical doctor to certify him/her fit for the programme. The medical examination will be arranged by and paid for by the school.
